items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30pm today, Thursday 17th February and 1:30am Friday 18th February.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.74 mAODN at half past midnight, on Friday 18th February, which is 0.64m above tide tables, wind Force 4, Southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation. There are likely to be further flood alerts issued with Storm Eunice pushing in.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 9pm and 11pm today, Thursday 17th February.  We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.64 mAODN at 10pm, on Thursday 17th February, which is 0.6m above tide tables, wind Force 5, South-Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation. There are likely to be further flood alerts issued with Storm Eunice pushing in.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely overnight this evening ,Thursday 17th February, and into tomorrow, Friday 18th February. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. There is heightened risk from overtopping at Haddiscoe New Cut as the embankment level has been reduced. We have reduced our Flood Alert threshold and we are undertaking emergency repairs and planned future works to bring the embankment back up to condition.  Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 18th February.

Levels are now forecast to be below the flood risk thresholds for the next few tides. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. At present we are not expecting to experience further high tides which are above the flood alert thresholds for the next few tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation with Storm Eunice and will issue warnings as needed.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force for this evening’s tide, Thursday 17/02/2022, between 5:00 PM and 9:00 PM. Strong winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast during this time. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea Village. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and it is likely this alert will be needed on Friday 18/02/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been re-issued as strong winds may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Thursday 17/02/2022 and Friday 18/02/2022. Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point. Flooding is expected from overtopping waves and spray from 5:30PM until 8:00PM on Thursday 17/02/2022, and from 07:00AM until 08:30AM on Friday 18/02/2022. We are closely monitoring the forecast conditions. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to avoid coastal roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely overnight this evening, Thursday 17th February, and into tomorrow Friday 18th February. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. There is heightened risk from overtopping at Haddiscoe New Cut as the embankment level has been reduced. We have reduced our Flood Alert threshold and we are undertaking emergency repairs and planned future works to bring the embankment back up to condition.  Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 18th February.

Storm Eunice is expected to bring severe gale force winds across the Somerset coast early Friday and into Saturday, coinciding with spring tides. We are expecting this to cause very large and powerful waves along the coast, with associated sea spray. First forecast high water is 07:45 on 18/2/22 with a level of 6.7 mAOD and a Force 8 South-westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 20:00 on 18/2/22 with a level of 6.2 mAOD and a Force 7 South-westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point; mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to coastal properties, roads, footpaths and farmland is possible two to three hours either side of the high tides. Please be careful and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.
Coastal conditions should ease for the high tide at 08:30 on Saturday,19/2/22.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and we are closely monitoring the situation.  
We will update this message as the situation changes and new information is available.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.74mAOD at 15:00 on 17/02/2022 and 4.60mAOD at 03:30 on 18/02/2022.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 120 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 18/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

Tide levels are not expected to reach alert level for the next high tide, at just after midnight tonight, Thursday. However, due to Storm Eunice we are expecting the lunchtime tide tomorrow Friday to reach alert and in some cases warning level for some locations. With further unsettled weather we expect higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert and any warnings as necessary. Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: This Flood Alert was issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:30PM on Wednesday 16/02/22, with impacts possible two hours before and after this time. Storm Dudley was forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. This tide has now passed. However, we expect Storm Eunice to affect the coast over the next few days, and with increasing spring tides the effects are predicted to intensify. The high tide on Friday 18/02/22 midday is also expected to reach Flood Alert level, and we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings over the next 2-3 days, depending on the path of the next storm. We will continue to monitor levels closely and our incident response staff will be out checking defences and closing flood gates where necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will update this message tomorrow morning 18/02/22 or as the situation changes.

Storm Eunice is expected to cause higher tides than usual due to the forecast weather conditions. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Howley, Bank Quay, Fiddlers Ferry, Knutsford Road, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge between 12:30PM and 02:30PM, 18/02/2022. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high as a result of recent heavy rain, on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, and Derwentwater, though they are falling slowly. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the lake frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site today, Thursday 17/02/2022. Flooding of properties is not expected. Today’s forecast is largely dry and we expect the level of Derwentwater to continue to fall. However, levels are expected to rise again in response to further rain associated with Storms Eunice, which is forecast to start in the early hours of Friday and continue through the day. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near Derwentwater and local watercourses which may be flooded, and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels remain high on Windermere and the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and their tributaries following recent heavy rainfall, and Newby Bridge Sluices remain open. Areas most at risk include low lying areas around Grasmere, Rydal, Ambleside, Windermere, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Today, Thursday 17/02/2022, is forecast to be mostly dry but the lake level in particular will remain raised, and levels are expected to rise again in response to further rain associated with Storms Eunice, which is forecast to start in the early hours of Friday and continue through the day. River and lake levels are expected to remain high over the next few days. We do not expect flooding to properties. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages and clearing debris screens. This message will be updated tomorrow Friday 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are now falling and are expected to continue to fall overnight and into tomorrow, Thursday 17th February. 
On Friday (February 18th) Storm Eunice is expected to bring further heavy rain and snow, as well as very strong winds.  Given the stormy conditions, stay well away from watercourses and be aware of debris and surface water affecting roads. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will issue further flood alerts and warnings if necessary, over the next few days.

River Levels in the Upper River Aire have now fallen below the flood risk threshold and are no longer filling the washlands. As there is no further significant rainfall forecast today, Thursday 17th February. Washlands at Snaygill Ings, Skipton and Cononley are draining steadily but will still contain water for some time as this process takes place. 

On Friday Storm Eunice is expected to bring further heavy rain and snow, as well as very strong winds.  Given the stormy conditions, stay well away from watercourses and flood water and be aware of debris and surface water affecting roads. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will issue further flood alerts and warnings if necessary over the next few days.

River levels have risen at all river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 4m to 4.3m Friday evening;  Cae Howel is 4.2m and slowly rising.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning by 10am, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Mordiford river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. River levels have risen and are expected to stay high, falling slightly and rising again to at all gauge locations due to forecast storm Eunice. Peaks: Hay-on-Wye peaked at 2.64m last night; Bredwardine 4.65m early this morning; Belmont peaked at 4.7 at midday, Hereford peaked at 4.2m this afternoon, predicted peaks; Mordiford peaking at 4.3m this afternoon, Ross on Wye 3.6 to 4.1 this evening. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on Friday 18/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse remains in force as levels remain high due to recent heavy rain. Further rainfall is forecast for Friday 18/02/2022 and over the weekend which may see levels rise again. The River Ouse in York has peaked at around 2.5m. Levels are expected to start falling during Thursday evening 17/02/2022. Levels at Naburn will remain around 2.1m on Thursday but are expected to start falling during Friday. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as levels remain high on the River Ouse, due to recent heavy rain. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land most affected, particularly around Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. The River Ouse in York has peaked at around 2.5m. Levels are expected to start falling during Thursday evening 17/02/2022. Further rainfall is forecast for Friday 18/02/2022 and over the weekend which may see levels rise again. We will continue to monitor levels closely. The Foss Barrier has not been operated today as levels were not high enough to require it. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn  bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.85m  Thursday afternoon, Montford 5.1m to 5.4m Friday late evening, Welshbridge 2.8m to 3.1m Friday lunchtime, Buildwas 4m to 4.4m Friday evening, Bridgnorth 3.3 to 3.6m Saturday morning.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning by 10am, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high and are forecast to rise at the Ross-On-Wye and Lydbrook river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. We expect river levels to remain high for several days. Predicted Peaks: Ross on Wye 3.6 to 4.1m this evening, Lydrbrook 4.3 to 4.8m Thursday night,17/02/22. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10am on Friday, 18/02/22 or as the situation changes.

The level of Derwentwater continues to fall but remains high following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the lake frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site today, Thursday 17/02/2022. Flooding of properties is not expected though the campsite itself remains closed. Today’s forecast is largely dry and we expect the level of Derwentwater to continue to fall. However, levels are expected to rise again in response to further rain associated with Storm Eunice, which is forecast to start in the early hours of Friday and continue through the day. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near Derwentwater and local watercourses, which may be flooded and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert has now been removed as levels of on the River Nidd have fallen. Further heavy rain is forecast on Friday 18/02/2022. Our incident staff will continue to monitor the situation and may re-issue the alert if required. Check gov.uk pages for a full 5 day forecast.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Little Alne river gauge as a result of expected rainfall overnight and tomorrow, Friday 18/02/2022 as a result of Storm Eunice.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible early tomorrow morning, Friday 18/02/2022.

Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Friday 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high and continue to rise slowly on the River Thame following rainfall over the last few days. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 17/02/2022, especially in areas close to the River Thame in the Thame and Stadhampton areas.
 
Today will be mainly dry with a few scattered showers this afternoon. Further rainfall is forecast overnight and tomorrow with the potential to be heavy at times. 

River levels are high but beginning to stabilise around the Thame area. Levels downstream continue to rise around Stadhampton as water makes its way downstream. Levels upstream of Thame do not currently pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Middle River Roding as a result of heavy rainfall. River levels are expected to remain high throughout Thursday 17 February. Flooding to roads and low-lying land, particularly around Abridge, is possible. 

Please be aware there are high wind speeds expected in the coming days.

We are closely monitoring the situation, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  

You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.
  
This message will be updated this evening 17/2/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen at present at the Eathorpe gauge. Further rainfall is forecast as a result of Storm Eunice overnight and tomorrow, Friday 18/02/2022. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to be affecting low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. The Severn Ham at Tewkesbury starts to fill. Predicted peaks at Mythe river gauge are between 3.6 to 4.1m Monday,21/02/22. River levels are expected to remain high for some time. More rain is forecast over the next few days that may cause river levels to rise further. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 18/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Storm Eunice is expected to bring severe gale force winds across the Bristol Channel early on Friday, coinciding with low spring tides. We are expecting this to cause very large and powerful waves along the coast. 
Forecast high water is 08:15 on 18/02/22 with a level of 7.43 mAOD and a Force 9 South Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
We expect flooding to affect the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and liaising with emergency services.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
We will update this message as the situation changes and new information is available.

Tide levels are not expected to reach alert level for the next high tide, at just after midnight tonight, Thursday. However, due to Storm Eunice we are expecting the lunchtime tide tomorrow Friday to reach alert and in some cases warning level for some locations. With further unsettled weather we expect higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert and any warnings as necessary. Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
The arrival of Storm Eunice Overnight on Thursday has the potential to cause severe flooding with overtopping of defences, very strong winds and high waves. There is potential for record water levels along the Severn & Wye estuaries.  
There is likely to be severe impacts to communities along the Severn & Wye, with people and property affected on Friday morning over the high tide period. 
Please stay away from the Estuary and implement your flood plan. Please avoid low lying roads and footpaths during this time. 
There is potential for high water levels between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning
Please stay alert as flood warnings will be issued for your community tomorrow morning.
This message will be superseded by flood warnings.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high but within banks on the River Ray. Levels are gradually rising as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and farmland is possible this afternoon, 17/02/2022, and in the areas around Islip.

Today will be mainly dry with a few scattered showers this afternoon. Further rainfall is forecast overnight and tomorrow with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to slowly rise this morning before stabilising this afternoon. Levels are currently within banks but remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert was issued due to the high tide and waves forecast at 11:30 PM on Wednesday, 16/02/2022. This tide has now passed. However, we expect Storm Eunice to affect the coast over the next few days, and with increasing spring tides, the effects are predicted to intensify. We are expecting to reach Flood Alert level again at the midday high tide on Friday, 18/02/2022, and we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings over the next 2-3 days, depending on the path of the next storm. We will continue to monitor levels closely and our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning on 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Westbury, Broadoak and Newnham on the Severn Estuary
items.message: A severe flood warning is in force for Westbury, Broadoak and Newnham on the Severn Estuary. Severe flooding is expected from Friday morning due to strong winds, high waves and a high tide between 07:30 and 11:30, 18/02/2022. There is danger to life. You need to take action immediately to implement your emergency flood plan as severe flooding to homes and main roads is expected. The level at the Sharpness gauge will reach up to 10.8mASD during the high tide tomorrow morning and levels will remain high for a prolonged period of time due to a tidal surge with very strong winds and large waves.. We are working closely with emergency services. If you feel your life is threatened, please dial 999 for assistance. This message will be updated by midday on 18/02/2022.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from The Rumps to Hartland Point excluding Bude
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning and evening high tides on Friday 18th February. High water at Padstow is at 6.21am and 6.41pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Storm force 10 west-southwesterly winds and offshore wave heights up to 9m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including Port Quin, Port Isaac, Trebarwith Strand and Boscastle.
Expect the high tide on Friday morning to be up to 740mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. Coastal conditions are expected to ease slightly for Friday evening’s high tide, but remain above flood alert criteria.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. Further flood warnings may be required over this period.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Padstow on Friday morning is 4.06 mAOD, this is 0.47 metres above astronomical tide level.

Areas most at risk include Chesil Bank and The Fleet Nature Reserve and Ferry Bridge Marine Services, Portland Beach Road.
The forecast high water for Chiswell is at 07:51 AM on 18/02/2022 with a level of 1.81 mAODN with south-westerly force 9 winds and waves of 5.3 metres. (mAODN is height above average sea level)
Storm Eunice is forecast to produce a large offshore tidal surge which will increase water levels for one to two hours either side of high water.
We are activating flood signs at Wyke Regis and Portland.
We are working with emergency services and local authorities and are closely monitoring the situation.
Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 01:30 PM on 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.

Friday afternoon's tide at 12:30 on 18/02/2022 is higher than normal due to Storm Eunice which brings Severe Gale Force 9 South Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.67 m. The total forecast tide is 5.38 metres Chart Datum (2.65 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, road and car park flooding will occur at Langstone High Street, Royal Oak, Ship Inn Pub (Langstone), South Street, Queen Street and A259 Junction of Lumley Road. Large waves will overtop at Emsworth Promenade, although the promenade may also become open harbour. Isolated property flooding could occur. Tide levels remain a little elevated on Saturday 19/02/22 at 13:00, although any impacts from this tide are likely to be very minor. We may issue further advice tomorrow. To help protect property, we have installed drop boards at Emsworth Promenade. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update or remove this message by 18:00 on 18/02/2022.

River levels are rising due to recent rain. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to start this afternoon 17/02/22.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting Worcester racecourse and County cricket ground. Predicted peak for the Diglis gauge is 2.8 to 3.2m overnight on 17/02.   

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 72 hours. River levels have started rising today, 17/02/22 and we expect this to continue until Sunday 20/02/22.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 18/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Friday afternoon's tide at 12:06 on 18/02/2022 is higher than normal due to Storm Eunice which brings Severe Gale Force 9 South Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.8 m. The total forecast tide is 5.06 metres Chart Datum (2.47 mAOD) at Cowes. Forecast levels are high, and water will come close to property. For 1 hour either side of high water, sea front roads, esplanades and car parks will flood. In Cowes, water will impact the High Street, Medina Road (floating bridge) and Sea Street (Newport). In East Cowes, sea water forced up through drains will impact roads at Albany Road, York Avenue and Castle Street. The ferry terminal at Yarmouth will flood. Tide levels remain a little elevated on Saturday 19/02/22 at 12:30, although any impacts are likely to be minor. We may issue further advice tomorrow. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection at Medina Road (Cowes) Well Road (East Cowes) and Bridge Road (Yarmouth), 1 hour before high tide. We will update or remove this message by 18:00 on 18/02/2022.

Road and car park flooding is expected at Ashlett Creek, Calshot Activity Centre, Hythe sea front, Promenade, Shore Road and High Street (Hythe); Magazine Lane (Marchwood), Woodmill Lane, Priory Road (St Denys), Quay and Rope Walk (Hamble), Shore Road (Warsash), outbuildings at Fawley Refinery, boat yards at Bursledon and Swanwick. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. At Priory Road, residents may wish to install flood protection. Please keep away from the sea front at high tide. Strong winds can carry and throw debris. We will remove this message by 18:00 on 18/02/2022.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lands End to Lizard Point excluding Mounts Bay
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected over the high tide on Friday morning 18th February 2022.  High water at Newlyn is at 5:45am, times of high water will vary along the coast.  

Strong Gale force 9 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 9m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including Mousehole, Praa Sands, Porthleven and Mullion.  Flooding is possible approximately two hours either side of high tide.  

Expect tides to be around 460mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.  

Please take extreme care around the coast, storm force winds and large waves will cause significantly hazardous conditions. Do not drive through flood water or waves.   

Coastal conditions should ease for Friday evening’s high tide, however strong winds and large waves are forecast. We are continuing to monitor the situation and will issue updates if the situation changes. 

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 2.93 mAOD, this is 0.46 metres above astronomical tide level.

The weather increases tide table values by 0.8 m. The total forecast tide is 5.37 metres Chart Datum (2.63 mAOD) at Southampton. For 1.5 hours either side of high water, levels in the lower River Itchen will increase as the incoming tide prevents water from flowing out to sea. Footpath flooding will affect some areas of Riverside Park. The pub car park at Mansbridge may also experience some minor impact flooding for a very short period of time. The tide is unlikely to flood the A27. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. As a precautionary measure, we recommend closing the defence gates around the pub. Avoid walking in flooded areas of Riverside Park. We will remove this message by 18:00 on 18/02/2022.

Friday morning's tide at 11:54 on 18/02/2022 and 14:08 on 18/02/2022 is higher than normal due to Storm Eunice which brings Severe Gale Force 9 South Westerly winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.8 m. The total forecast tide is 4.42 metres Chart Datum (2.42 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 1 hour either side of high water, Palace Lane and the B3056 (Hatchet Lane) north of the pond will flood, making access to the village more difficult. On the downstream side of the pond, the Mill house may flood, along with outbuildings and garages. Shepherds Mead is vulnerable, as cars driving through flooded roads cause bow waves, forcing water towards property. Tide levels remain a little elevated on Saturday 19/02/22 at 12:30, although any impacts from this tide are likely to be very minor. We may issue further advice tomorrow. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. At Hatchet Lane, driving through flood water can flood property. We will update or remove this message by 18:00 on 18/02/2022.

Friday afternoon's tide at 12:15 on 18/02/2022 is higher than normal due to Storm Eunice which brings Severe Gale Force 9 Westerly winds and very large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.64 m. The total forecast tide is 6.31 metres Chart Datum (3.26 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, waves will overtop the sea front. Water will flow westwards along Mill Lane and Climping Street (from the right of the East car park) ponding in Climping Street car park, near to properties, and in nearby land and fields. Friday evening’s tide will be 50cm lower. However strong winds and large waves will continue over the weekend, albeit not as extreme. Saturday’s midday tide could see a return of minor flood impacts, when tide levels could be similar to midday Friday. We continue to monitor the forecast and have staff on standby to check the condition of the beach at Climping. Please take action to protect property on Climping Street at least 2 hours before high tide. Avoid visiting the sea front. We will update this message by 18:00 on 18/02/2022.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
The arrival of Storm Eunice overnight on Thursday has the potential to cause severe flooding with overtopping of defences, very strong winds and high waves. There is potential for record water levels along the Severn & Wye estuary. 
Water levels will be at their highest between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning when flooding to properties, roads and farmland is expected. The level at Gloucester gauge is forecast to reach up to 4.0m . The level at Sandhurst gauge is forecast to reach up to 4.0m on Friday morning. This warning has been issued due to the high tidal surge, significant wave height and wind speed which will cause levels to remain high for a longer period of time. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and working closely with our partners. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please activate your flood plan, and avoid using low lying footpaths and roads during this time.
This message will be updated by Midday, 18/02/22 or if the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Dunster Beaches, seafront and chalet area
items.message: Storm Eunice is expected to bring severe gale force winds across the Somerset coast early Friday and into Saturday, coinciding with spring tides. We are expecting this to cause very large and powerful waves along the coast, overtopping of sea defences is expected in places. Forecast high water is 07:45 on 18/2/22 with a level of 6.7 mAOD and a Force 8 South-west wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point; mAOD is height above average sea level. Flooding is possible two to three hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the Warren and Sea Lane End including Dunster Beach Chalets. Please be careful, especially along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. Coastal conditions should ease for the high tide at 08:30 on Saturday,19/2/22. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and we are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message as the situation changes and new information is available.

items.description: Coast from Fairlight to Dungeness including the Tidal Rother
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to affect coastal areas between Fairlight and Dungeness as a result of Storm EUNICE during Friday 18 February 2022.  Tides will be at their highest between 11:15 and 13:15 tomorrow, Friday 18 February. A peak level of 4.22metres above Ordnance Datum is forecast at Rye Harbour at 12:15. Due to the strong south-westerly winds, levels may remain high for the rest of the day.  Flooding may affect locations near the coast throughout this area, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Pett, Rye Harbour, and Lydd Ranges.   Strong winds may cause wave overtopping throughout the day and winds are not expected to ease until Friday evening.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and members of the public are advised to stay away from frontages, due to the risk of wave overtopping.
This message will be updated during the evening of Friday 18 February 2022, or as the situation changes.
